Description: A plant of the drift-line and cliffs on sandy and rocky shores[17].
Coasts of Europe, including Britain, from the Netherlands to N. Spain, Mediterranean, Black Sea.

Raphanus maritima is a BIENNIAL growing to 0.8 m (2ft 7in).  It is not frost tender.  It is in flower from June to August. The species is hermaphrodite (has both male and female organs) and is pollinated by Bees, flies.  Suitable for: light (sandy), medium (loamy) and heavy (clay) soils. Suitable pH: mildly acid, neutral and basic (mildly alkaline) soils. It can grow in  semi-shade (light woodland) or no shade. It prefers  moist soil. The plant can tolerate maritime exposure.
Flowers: ,Leaves: ,Root: includes bulbs, corms, tubers, rhizomes etc.,Seedpod: things such as Okra, French and Runner beans.

Young leaves - raw or cooked as a potherb[2, 183]. A somewhat hot taste. Root - cooked as a potherb or used as a substitute for horseradish[2, 183]. Flowers - raw. A nice addition to salads. Young seedpods - raw. Crisp and juicy, they must be eaten when young because they quickly become tough and fibrous.

Prefers a rich soil with ample moisture[16, 52]. Dislikes very heavy soils[37]. The seeds are dispersed by sea-water, in which they can float for 7 - 10 days without loss of viability[17].
Seed - sow spring in situ. Germination should take place within 2 weeks.
